The real Santa Claus is the one that‚Äôs right in front of your kid. There is a special place in Hell for anyone who breaks the Santa Code of Ethics. One of the best Christmas stories ever was an episode of the Amos and Andy TV series from 1952. I saw it about three or four years later and it stuck with me to this day. Andy takes a job as a department store Santa. You can find it on YouTube and you will see what the Santa Thing is all about. Amos ‚ÄòN Andy- The Christmas Story. I loved Amos ‚ÄòN Andy and it was a shame that they called it racist. Many of the characters reminded me of the Italian branch of my family. The situations they got into translates across every ethnicity. I‚Äôm glad that Andy taught me the truth about Santa when I was six, because it protected me from the horrific scene I witnessed years later. My uncle was an entertainer for the lack of a better description. I think his most important roll was a walk-on in an episode of Car 54. He was also a professional clown and I think his work was like a substitute teacher when the regular teacher gets sick. He took me to see a buddy of his doing a clown gig at a Christmas party at a service club where he did the usual clown stuff and magic. After his act, Santa Claus did his thing. Later on during a break, I witnessed my uncle, Santa Claus and that malevolent clown at the bar smoking cigarettes and draining a bottle of whiskey. It was like some Quentin Tarantino movie and it was a good thing the little ones were off with cake and ice cream otherwise if they had seen that, we would have had a new crop of serial killers on the loose.

Now there was a Real Saint Nickolas .The true story of Santa Claus begins with Nicholas, who was born during the third century in the village of Patara in Asia Minor. At the time the area was Greek and is now on the southern coast of Turkey. His wealthy parents, who raised him to be a devout Christian, died in an epidemic while Nicholas was still young. Obeying Jesus‚Äô words to ‚Äúsell what you own and give the money to the poor,‚Äù Nicholas used his whole inheritance to assist the needy, the sick, and the suffering. He dedicated his life to serving God and was made Bishop of Myra while still a young man. Bishop Nicholas became known throughout the land for his generosity to those in need, his love for children, and his concern for sailors and ships.

Under the Roman Emperor Diocletian, who ruthlessly persecuted Christians, Bishop Nicholas suffered for his faith, was exiled and imprisoned. The prisons were so full of bishops, priests, and deacons, there was no room for the real criminals‚Äîmurderers, thieves and robbers. After his release, Nicholas attended the Council of Nicaea in AD 325. He died December 6, AD 343 in Myra and was buried in his cathedral church, where a unique relic, called manna, formed in his grave. This liquid substance, said to have healing powers, fostered the growth of devotion to Nicholas. The anniversary of his death became a day of celebration, St. Nicholas Day, December 6th (December 19 on the Julian Calendar).

Through the centuries many stories and legends have been told of St. Nicholas‚Äô life and deeds. These accounts help us understand his extraordinary character and why he is so beloved and revered as protector and helper of those in need.

@Eva Bartlett I, too, am a Christian. Jesus found me and leads me to His Word. I find a historically correct usage of Greek (Hebrew, Aramaic, the languages the Bible is written in) terms and abbreviations inoffensive because I understand the reasoning behind them.

As long as the G was capitalized and the meaning is clear, why should it be disrespectful? My name is Kimberly but people call me Kim all the time. Should I take offense because they shortened my name?

The swastika, a universally disliked/abhorrent symbol is also, when reversed, a Hindu (I believe) symbol of hope. Yes an X can mean crossed out but the chi, also an X, is a symbol of Christ. Have you ever seen an Icthus? You know, the fish symbol? It's the same thing. Who would believe that Jesus could be equaled to a fish? People in the know realize that we're not saying Jesus is a fish but the Icthus is actually a creed; Jesus Christ, Son of God, Savior.

Why this bothers me? Because "yelling" at people for something like this, instead of taking it as an opportunity to educate and WITNESS to Christ's Gospel truth, is a wasted effort. In my opinion.
